item.title: Morsi’s Fall in Egypt Lauded by Syria’s Assad
item.description: The Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, sees the fall of Mohamed Morsi as a vindication of his government’s fight against the two-year Syrian uprising.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Quito Journal: Ecuador, Possible Snowden Haven, Is High on Beauty but Low on Tech
item.description: If granted asylum — a big if — the N.S.A. leaker Edward J. Snowden would likely find life in tiny, beautiful, impoverished Ecuador a bit of an adjustment.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cody Leigh Brown, 30, a Montanan who moved to Ecuador four years ago, owns the Bigoté tea shop in a Quito suburb.

item.title: Jurist Sworn In to Lead Egypt Transition
item.description: Egypt’s new acting head of state, Adli Mansour, offered an olive branch to the Muslim Brotherhood supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the deposed leader, but the Islamist group appeared to rule out any reconciliation.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Adli Mansour, center, spoke on Thursday during his swearing-in ceremony as Egypt's interim president.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 4
item.description: A building collapsed in Bhiwandi on the outskirts of Mumbai, Maharashtra on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Rescue personnel gathering at the site of a collapsed building in Bhiwandi on the outskirts of Mumbai, Maharashtra. According to local media reports, one person died.

item.title: Six Children Killed by Hidden Bombs in Afghanistan
item.description: Four girls at a wedding party and two boys walking home from school died in two roadside blasts.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and HABIB ZAHORI

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Egypt’s Political Crisis
item.description: The Lede is following events in Egypt, where its military rulers ousted President Mohamed Morsi on Wednesday and moved to devise an interim government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY, LIAM STACK and MONA EL NAGGAR
item.media:description: A screenshot of the travel warning posted on the Web site of the United States Embassy in Cairo.

item.title: Campaign for Parliamentary Election Begins in Japan
item.description: At stake in the election are half of the seats in the upper house of Parliament, and polls are forecasting major gains for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and his economic revival plan.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Ouster of Egyptian Leader Draws Divided Response
item.description: The reactions of Egypt’s neighbors and partners largely reflected their own perceptions of the threats they face at home from either militant Islam or their armed forces.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Mandela’s Grandson Ends Battle Over Burials
item.description: Mandla Mandela, the eldest grandson of the ailing Nelson Mandela, said Thursday that he would give up his fight with other family members over where to bury three of the former president’s children.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: North and South Korea to Meet About Industrial Park
item.description: A South Korean-run industrial complex in North Korea has been idle since April, when tensions between the two nations reached a high point.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: Hindi Paper Finds Success Going Hyperlocal
item.description: A Hindi newspaper grows after embracing advocacy journalism and hyperlocal editions in small towns and rural India.
item.dc:creator: By VINAY SITAPATI
item.media:description: The Rajasthan Patrika headquarters in Kesargarh, Rajasthan.

item.title: Barring of Bolivian Plane Infuriates Latin America as Snowden Case Widens
item.description: Latin American leaders condemned the refusal to let Bolivia’s president fly over European nations over what Bolivian officials said were suspicions that Edward J. Snowden was on board.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Bolivia’s president, Evo Morales, speaking to reporters at an airport near Vienna. France and Portugal had blocked his plane.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Mandela: Inspiration for an Era of Activism
item.description: In the welter of memories surrounding Nelson Mandela, it is worth noting the role he played as an inspiration to other anti-apartheid fighters during the long years of his imprisonment.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Ahead of Elections, India Passes Food Security Law
item.description: Frustrated by delays in Parliament, India’s cabinet on Thursday approved a sweeping executive order that establishes a legal right to food and will create what is likely the world’s largest food subsidy system for the poor.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Laborers loading sacks of wheat onto a truck in the outskirts of Amritsar, Punjab, on May 16.

item.title: On Tape, Murdoch Criticizes Hacking Investigators, Broadcaster Says
item.description: A British station broadcast what appeared to be a recording of Rupert Murdoch criticizing the police investigation of Britain’s phone-hacking scandal as “totally incompetent.”
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Malaysia Denies Entry to Journalist
item.description: Clare Rewcastle Brown, the sister-in-law of former Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain, is the founder of news outlets that have taken on the Malaysian government.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: For Egypt’s Islamists, Confusion and Fear Amid Celebration
item.description: As much of Cairo exploded in euphoria, parts of the city fell silent where President Mohamed Morsi’s loyalists protested to stave off what they saw as a threat to democracy.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scenes in Cairo on Wednesday included a woman in tears outside the presidential palace.

item.title: Ambassador Becomes Focus of Egyptians’ Mistrust of U.S.
item.description: Anne W. Patterson, a press-shy career diplomat who has been American ambassador to Cairo since 2011, has suddenly found herself a target in a dangerous political upheaval.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Lithuania Aims for Energy Independence
item.description: With a high-tech ship, the country is hoping to break free of its dependence on Gazprom for its natural gas.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Alnis Stakle for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: The spot just off Kiaules Nugara, an island off the coast of Lithuania, where officials hope to moor a ship that will process liquefied natural gas into fuel for the nation.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Cuba: Communist Party Leaders Ousted
item.description: Cuba’s president, Raúl Castro, has announced the removal of the former Parliament chief Ricardo Alarcón and several other leaders from the Communist Party’s Central Committee.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: England: Herbal Stimulant Is Banned
item.description: The British government said Wednesday that it was banning qat, an herbal stimulant, despite advice against such a step by an official advisory body.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Offer to Return Remains of Chinese Troops Killed in Korean War
item.description: The remains of hundreds of Chinese soldiers killed in the Korean War may finally return home, 60 years after an armistice ended the fighting.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Time Magazine Is Banned
item.description: A customs official said that Sri Lanka had banned this week’s issue of Time magazine over its cover story on Myanmar’s sectarian violence between Buddhists and Muslims.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: King Says He Will Abdicate
item.description: King Albert II of Belgium announced Wednesday that he would abdicate in favor of Crown Prince Philippe on July 21.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lawmakers Question White House Account of an Internet Surveillance Program
item.description: Some lawmakers are expressing skepticism not only about the value of the domestic surveillance programs but also about the accuracy with which the administration has described them.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES RISEN
